commit.message:
corestripper: Fix uninitialized warning

Clang finds more open paths where ret can be uninitialized

Fixes
| ../../../git/src/minicoredumper/corestripper.c:2768:13: error: variable 'ret' is used uninitialized whenever 'if' condition is false [-Werror,-Wsometimes-uninitialized]
|  2768 |         } else if (di->core_fd >= 0) {
|       |                    ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
| ../../../git/src/minicoredumper/corestripper.c:2773:9: note: uninitialized use occurs here
|  2773 |         return ret;
|       |                ^~~
| ../../../git/src/minicoredumper/corestripper.c:2768:9: note: remove the 'if' if its condition is always true
|  2768 |         } else if (di->core_fd >= 0) {
|       |                ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
| ../../../git/src/minicoredumper/corestripper.c:2763:9: note: initialize the variable 'ret' to silence this warning
|  2763 |         int ret;
|       |                ^
|       |                 = 0

Signed-off-by: Khem Raj <raj.khem@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

init: fixup debian comment

The LSB functions are now provided by the essential sysvinit-utils
package. Update the comments to mention this.

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

release: version 2.0.7

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

minicoredumper: only dump to core for crash process

dump_data_content() is used to dump core and external data
files for both the crashing process and any other applications
registered with the minicoredumper.

For the non-crashing process there is no core file to dump to,
but dump_data_content() does not consider this and attempts
anyway. This leads to error messages that can mislead the user
to think there was a problem.

Adjust dump_data_content() to only attempt dumping to a core
file if a core file is available.

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

minicoredumper: fix dump of robust mutex list with pi

glibc uses bit0 of the robust mutex list pointers as a flag for
PI (priority inheritance) mutexes. The minicoredumper was not
masking the flag before trying to interpret the address. This
led to the wrong pointer data being dumped into the core file
if any of the locked robust mutexese are using the
PTHREAD_PRIO_INHERIT attribute.

Mask bit0 before interpretting the robust mutex list pointers.

Also cleanup the list iterating so that it is easier to follow
and does not treat the head as an extra mutex.

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

docs: convert README to markdown

The README gets a lot of views on github. Convert to markdown and
clean up the formatting so that it looks pretty on github.

Also add information about maintenance by Linutronix.

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>
Reviewed-by: Wilfried Wessner <wilfried.wessner@linutronix.de>

release: version 2.0.6

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

minicoredumper: support comm values with spaces

A comm string may contain spaces, which would cause the
minicoredumper to choose the wrong item for the thread
stack when parsing proc/stat. This results in the
minicoredumper failing to copy the stack for some threads.

For the comm item, explicitly check for the terminating
parenthesis before continuing to the next item. Note
that the error is still possible if ") " is within
comm. But this is really a limitation of the primitive
format of proc/stat.

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

release: version 2.0.5

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

minicoredumper: also dump write-only vma's

Minicoredumper only dumps memory segments that are marked with
the readable flag (PF_R). However, write-only memory segments
are dumped by the kernel and should therefore also be dumped
by minicordumper. An example of such a segment is allocating
memory via mmap():

mmap(NULL, 4096, PROT_WRITE, MAP_PRIVATE | MAP_ANONYMOUS, -1, 0);

Modify the vma parser to also accept any segment where the
writable flag (PF_W) is set.

Reported-by: github.com/sehdshskj
Suggested-by: github.com/sehdshskj
Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

release: version 2.0.4

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

minicoredumper: add eof check for read_file_fd()

Commit a09461321cb8 ("minicoredumper: treat eof as error") added an eof
check to the higher-level copy_data() function, assuming that the
lower-level read_file_fd() could return 0. But actually that function
was not handling the eof and would instead go into an infinite loop.

read() can return 0 if the crashing process is killed (for example with
explicit SIGKILL) before the minicoredumper is finished reading the
memory.

The problem was reported and fixed by Dongyang. The original report:

    In the below situation, the read will in an infinite loop:

    If the PID 123 triggered the core dump and Minicoredumper started
    to read the /proc/123/mem (dump_compressed_tar-->copy_data-->read_file_fd).
    At this time, if the OOM is triggered, then the PID 123 is killed by
    SIGKILL. The /proc/123/ folder will nonexistent, the read will return zero. 

    But in the read_file_fd, the code doesn't check the zero condition.
    When the "r" is 0,  the "len" will never to 0,  then into an infinite loop. 

Fixes: a09461321cb8 ("minicoredumper: treat eof as error")
Signed-off-by: Dongyang <dongyang626@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Jianyu <jianyu9785@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

website: use xz for installation

xz is used for the release tarballs. Show this in the installation
commands.

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

release: version 2.0.3

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

minicoredumper: truncate tar core files to 8GB

The ustar format only has 11 octal characters available for specifying
sizes and offsets. So the maximum value is 077777777777 (8589934591).

Drop core data blocks and truncate the core file if it goes beyond this
limit. This is only a workaround until a more modern tar format is
implemented.

The discussion about this issue and the possible workarounds can be
seen on the mailing list:

https://lists.linutronix.de/pipermail/minicoredumper/2023-February/000126.html

In that thread it is also mentioned how an application can guarantee
thread stacks will not be truncated by placing them below the
anticipated heap area, thus placing them near the beginning of the
core file.

Reported-by: github.com/sehdshskj
Reported-by: Jos Hulzink (Ellips B.V.) <jos.hulzink@ellips.com>
Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

minicoredumper: dump zeros in 4kb blocks

Dumping zeros 1 byte at a time is horribly inefficient. If tar
files are used, this does not matter much. But it tar files are
not used, there may be gigabytes of zeros that need to be dumped.

Dumping the zeros in 4kb blocks is a huge improvement. Using
larger buffer sizes does not seem to add any noticeable speed
benefits.

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

minicoredumper_demo: Use 'optnone' attribute with clang

clang does not support optimize("On") yet, therefore use optnone which
should give intended results with clang compiler

Signed-off-by: Khem Raj <raj.khem@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

docs: mention setting kernel.core_pipe_limit

It is recommended to set kernel.core_pipe_limit to the maximum
value. Show that in the documentation.

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

website: restore original banner

Originally the "minicoredumper" title was shown shrinking. A later
version of bootstrap made it no longer work. Restore that look.

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

init: set max value in kernel.core_pipe_limit

The kernel defaults to 0 for kernel.core_pipe_limit. This special
value works because the kernel _does_ wait as long as the core file
pipe is open, which minicoredumper does not close until it is
finished.

However, this may be a kernel bug and it should not be relied upon.
Set kernel.core_pipe_limit to the maximum value on start and restore
it to 0 on stop.

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

init: return values on success

For the case where the regd daemon should not be started, there is
no return value. Return 0.

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

autotools: use new form of AC_CONFIG_FILES/AC_OUTPUT

From the autoconf manual:

"The use of AC_OUTPUT with arguments is deprecated. This obsoleted interface
is equivalent to:

AC_CONFIG_FILES(file...)
AC_CONFIG_COMMANDS([default], extra-cmds, init-cmds)
AC_OUTPUT"

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

autotools: replace obsolete AM_CONFIG_HEADER

As reported by autoreconf:

"warning: 'AM_CONFIG_HEADER': this macro is obsolete.
You should use the 'AC_CONFIG_HEADERS' macro instead."

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>

autotools: remove obsolete AC_HEADER_STDC

From the autoconf docs:

"This macro is obsolescent, as current systems have conforming header
files. New programs need not use this macro."

Signed-off-by: John Ogness <john.ogness@linutronix.de>
